title: co-op-announces-prestonpans-store-is-to-close
story: The firm employs  people at the supermarket at Links Shopping Centre on High Street.The news has been met with dismay in the community.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoI was sorry to hear about the closure of the Co-op in Prestonpans.ldquoIts late opening hours save local people having to travel out of town.ldquoIt also plays an important role in bringing people onto High Street and helping sustain other businesses.ldquoIt will be a worrying time for the employees, and it is important they are given full support to find other employment.Ms OrsquoDonnell added that she would like to see more investment in Prestonpans to help nurture local businesses and create employment.Fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoThis isnrsquot welcome news.ldquoObviously, we want that space open and operating so that it gives facilities for locals to use and also provides much-needed employment.The councillor said that he would be contacting the owners of the site to find out who the next tenant would be.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, added: ldquoWhilst it is very disappointing that the Co-op are closing their store at Preston Links, it strengthens Prestonpans Community Councilrsquos case for a fundamental review of our High Street.ldquoPrestonpans is one of East Lothianrsquos largest towns and deserves a High Street that can attract local shoppers and serve visitors along the John Muir Way.A spokesperson for Co-op said: ldquoThe Co-op is moving forward with real purpose and momentum, and while this usually involves the opening of new stores, we also have to make dficult decisions.ldquoAfter careful consideration, our store on High Street in Prestonpans will close. The last day of trading is expected to be in November.ldquoThis is no way a reflection of the hard work of colleagues, who have been informed, and every effort will be made to find alternative roles for them.ldquoWe would like to thank the community for its support over the years.

title: jaimes-brave-abseil-in-tribute-to-her-dad
story: Jaime Sutherland, of Rowanhill Close, Port Seton, is taking on the abseil in June in aid of Chest, Heart and Stroke Scotland ndash and in tribute to her dad Dave, a civilian police worker, who suffered a fatal heart attack when he was just  years old.Jaime told the Courier: ldquoI saw an advert for abseiling down the bridge on Facebook.ldquoIrsquod already been thinking about doing something to raise money for charity and this seemed the perfect thing.ldquoMy dad passed away in  and I wanted to do something in his memory.ldquoIrsquom not usually a daredevil, but Irsquom not too bad with heights.Jaime has already raised pound through her Everyday Hero page on Facebook.She added: ldquoAll my mates think that Irsquom a bit mad and I think my mum was shocked when I told her what I wanted to do. Irsquom excited, though.As well as studying for her Highers, the -year-old coaches youngsters at Tranent Amateur Swimming Club, as well as working for Splash Start, and she is a leguard at Seton Sands Holiday Park. She was also named Junior Volunteer of the Year at the Tranent and District Community Sport Club Awards in .Mum Lynn added: ldquoIrsquom extremely proud of her.ldquoI know that she suffered anxiety after her dad died, it was a dficult time, so to see her reach this point is amazing.ldquoShersquos always wanted to help other people and has shown maturity beyond her years.ldquoShe is extremely hard-working and a great example at age  to younger people.Jaimersquos younger brother Andrew, , is also extremely supportive of his sister, making a donation to her page with his own money, writing: ldquoSo proud of you sissy, good luck.The family are also organising a disco on June  to help raise extra money for the cause.Anyone wanting to help with raffle donations should email lynncsutherland@aolTo support Jaimersquos abseil, which takes place on June , visit here.

title: lothian-buses-drivers-balloted-over-possible-strike
story: Unite the union confirmed that it will formally ballot its membership at Lothian Buses for industrial action following overwhelming support in a consultative ballot.In a three-week-long ballot,  per cent of Unite members who voted indicated support to take industrial action.Lothian Buses, which has a number of services in East Lothian, has refuted ldquoany allegations of bullying.The move ndash which has no impact on East Coast Buses, which is a subsidiary company of Lothian Buses ndash follows a breakdown in negotiations with Lothian Buses management at the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service .Lyn Turner, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoUnite met with Lothian Buses management at ACAS and we entered those talks in good faith to find a resolution to this dispute.ldquoHowever, there was a refusal at the outset to reinstate facility time, which is a red line for us.ldquoWe have a number of outstanding issues in relation to procedural agreements, which includes on bullying and harassment.ldquoThis is illustrated by the decision to remove facility time for the two senior Unite representatives.ldquoThis decision in our view is trade union victimisation and we will now move to an employment tribunal.A spokeswoman for Lothian Buses said: ldquoDespite the fact that the union and the business attended talks with ACAS last week, Unite thus far seem unwilling to engage in serious discussion.ldquoWe absolutely refute any allegations of bullying.ldquoThe branch chair and secretary are allocated four days per month to attend to their union duties ndash time which is paid for by Lothian and is way above what we are required to provide by law.ldquoWe are at a loss to understand why the union hierarchy is intent on pursuing this damaging course of action that has the potential to impact on our customers.

title: bid-to-buy-site-for-multi-generational-hub-at-north-berwick-turned-down
story: North Berwick Community Development Company, which has more than , members, wants to buy a .-hectare site off the townrsquos Lime Grove.The site, which was previously home to a council depot, is owned by the local authority.A sub-group of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnershipwas formed three years ago with a view to carrying out a community asset transfer.Last Friday, their bid was turned down by the council, which felt there was ldquoinsufficient evidence that the move would ldquopromote or improve economic development, regeneration, public health, social wellbeing or environmental wellbeing.A five-page document posed questions about the projectrsquos funding, adding: ldquoThere are signicant costs attributable to the proposal .ldquoWhilst the business plan is well-structured, East Lothian Council are of the view that there is insufficient evidence that the signicant initial, short-term and long-term funding sources can be properly secured to deliver the proposal.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe asset transfer request was considered under the agreed process for community asset transfers.ldquoUnder the terms of the Community EmpowermentAct, it was considered that there was insufficient evidence presented that this request would result in community improvements as suggested, nor did the evidence provided concerning possible funding sources for the project.Full details of the decision have been provided to North Berwick Development Company, who have the right to apply to the council to review the decision.Last month, Lime Grove Asset Transfer Group, the NBCAP sub-group, unanimously agreed to appeal the decisionthe request was refused. The group was due to meet yesterday , with a view to deciding the next step.Members are also seeking advice from the Community Ownership Support Service, a Scottish Government-funded programme set up to help groups take on land or building assets for their community.Lesley Kay, chairwoman of Lime Grove Asset Transfer Group and a director of North Berwick Community Development Company, said: ldquoWe are obviously disappointed by this decision.ldquoA great deal of work and community engagement was done to prepare for the community asset transfer request. We will continue with our mission to create a space where people can come together to meet their needs and aspirations.The group wants the site, which has lain vacant for more than five years, transformed into a community hub which could host a youth space, a multi-purpose room for theatre and cinema, a cafe, a soft play area and a hostel. Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, said they would discuss the matter at their next meeting.Ward councillor Jeremy Findlay was hopeful the group would try again to satisfy the criteria of the council. He said: ldquoI think the basic concept is good. I just donrsquot think the long-term planning was sufficiently robust.

title: tranent-boxing-gym-owners-bid-to-raise-10000-for-family-of-bradley-welsh
story: Alex Brown, from Musselburgh, is hoping to raise pound, for the grieving family of the boxing coach and charity fundraiser, who was shot outside his home in the west end of Edinburgh on Wednesday evening.Alex, , who owns Ideal Flooring Solutions in Musselburgh, told the Courier: ldquoI knew Brad very well for about  years. We went to the same boxing gym."He was such a genuine guy, very charitable and worked hard to keep kids off the street and teach them respect and discipline through boxing.ldquoI laid flowers outside his gym near Holyrood, and last night had a small memorial there for him.ldquoI feel Edinburgh has lost a good son.Bradley Welsh was famous locally for his charity work, raising hundreds of thousands of pounds over the years for ious childrenrsquos charities in the Edinburgh area.Alex added: ldquoIrsquom still pretty cut up about whatrsquos happened. One of the saddest things are all the children in the future who didnrsquot get to meet him or be trained by him and feel that benefit.ldquoThe money from the crowdfunder will go to his family to ease their financial pressure at this hard time.More than pound, has already been raised on the JustGiving page, with messages on the page paying emotional tributes to the starrsquos tragic death.One person wrote: "You did so much for charity Brad, I never knew you well but it was a pleasure to meet you. I hope people realise what you gave to the young people from Edinburgh."Donate to the page here.

title: haddington-co-op-to-shut-for-three-weeks-for-refurbishment
story: The Co-op on Hopetoun Drive is set to temporarily close from Sunday before re-opening on May .The revamped shop will offer a wide range of fresh fruit and vegetables, healthy foods, meal ideas, wines and essentials.Vicki Mains, regional manager for Co-op, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be undertaking such a signicant investment in Haddington and wersquore confident that the improvements will help us to better serve the community. Itrsquos an exciting time for the whole team.ldquoCo-op is moving forward with a clear purpose and momentum. Our ambition is to ensure the store is a local hub, a real asset for the community.ldquoWe also want shoppers to know that they can become a co-owner and member of their Co-op. Our members make a dference locally and simply by swiping their membership card when they shop with us they are raising much-needed funding for organisations in their area who contribute to improving local le.A shop has been at the junction of Hopetoun Drive and Hawthornbank Road since shortly after the Second World War, with Co-op being in place for about  years.The store brings a funding boost locally through Co-oprsquos Membership scheme ndash members receive a five per cent reward on the purchase of own-brand products and services, with the Co-op donating a further one per cent to good causes.Causes in the area currently being supported include Gford Community Association, Blooming Haddington and Lothians Out Of School Care Network.Councillor Tom Trotter, Haddington and Lammermuir ward member, was pleased to see the commitment to the business.He said: ldquoAny business that is looking to expand here is more than welcome.ldquoIt is a well-used shop and they have taken that into account.

story: Butyoure stuck for what to do with the family, heres a few ideas of things going on around the county this weekend:. European Stone Stacking Championships, DunbarFUN with stones is promised as the European Stone Stacking Championshipsto Dunbar.The event brought , people to the town last April and this yearrsquos event is now about to take place for the third successive year.Competitors from throughout Europe are expected to travel to East Lothian ahead of the two-day competition, which takes place on Saturday and Sunday.There are four inidual competitions at the event, including the most stones balanced, the artistic stone stack, the junior championship and the overall stone stacking champion.The first competition on Saturday, from am to pm, is being held at the scenic Eye Cave Beach, below Dunbar Sea Cadet hall. Competitors face the challenge of balancing as many stones as possible vertically, with last yearrsquos winner managing to balance  stones.This is then followed by the balance against the clock adult competition, starting at pm, where competitors race against time to balance the most stones in a three-minute challenge.The following day, adults are given three hours to create anything from stone or found objects in the artistic competition, which starts at noon.There are further competitions for youngsters, with more information at stonestacking. title: young-girl-stuck-in-sinking-sands-at-aberlady-bay
story: Leanne Cochrane and her husband Thomas were walking on Aberlady Bay at low tide when their daughter got "pulled in by sinking sands".The family wanted to see the wrecks of the two midget submarines which are buried in the sand and, although quite far out from the coast road, can be viewed at low tide.Leanne said on Facebook that they were on theirjourney on the vast sands when the "horric experience" occurred.Her daughter was, she said, ldquoknees deep" in wet sand when her husband "tried to get her out"."He got pulled in as well but thank God they both got out," she said. "There are no warning signs out there.The response across the social media site was immediate with one person writing: ldquoGlad you are all fine - hope everyone shares this. It must have been terrying.With another saying: ldquoAberlady Bay is dangerous: the sand banks constantly move and the mud sucks you under. Not advisable to walk on it in the winter spring time.Someone  added: ldquoAn easy mistake for anyone to make I agree an information board would be good.Scott Ironside, the countryside ranger at nearby Seton Sands Holiday Park, told the Courier that the most important rule in such situations was not to panic."The more you move your legs, the more you get sucked in," he said." Keep arms up and outward. Remove backpacks etc. Spread body weight evenly and lie on your chest and raise your legs slowly up to ground level then crawl out. If a person nearby has a rope or a branch, thatrsquos better. There is a Bear Grylls video about this on YouTube which has good advice, especially for those who are stuck alone.The midget submarines at Aberlady Bay are XT-Craft, training versions of the X-Craft that attacked the German battleship Tirpitz in .In , two of these vessels were towed to Aberlady Bay and moored to a large concrete block, then used as target practice and gun tests by RAF aircraft.

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: we-can-undo-the-clearances-and-re-people-the-highlands-says-professor-jim-hunter
story: Professor Jim Hunter gazes down Strath Brora at the acres of turf and heather, gorse and bracken. Itrsquos an empty place of rolling hills and crags, wide-open skies, silver water, green turf and lonely beauty. For Hunter, though, the emptiness of the strath, north of the Dornoch Firth in Sutherlandrsquos east, is plain wrong. He points to the fields below us.ldquoYou could live herethere was a house you could afford, next to the loch with a beautul view, he says. ldquoThe Arsquos four miles away, so is the railway ndash this isnrsquot the back of beyond. If effort was put in, it could happen.He points again, to Carrol, a couple of cottages across Loch Brora. In , months after the once-thriving township was cleared and its homes destroyed, the Countess of Sutherland came here, then wrote to her husband, the Marquess of Stafford, of her ldquomelancholy at the sight. The couple would later become the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, and were the most notorious proponents of the Clearances.ldquoI find it extraordinary, says Hunter. ldquoThe countess writes about it almost asitrsquos an act of God that the place was devastated and in ruins but it was that way because she and her husband had ordered to it to be.Hunterrsquos a historian and a Highlander, and has a deep knowledge of the dark blot on Scotlandrsquos story when much of the population was removed from the land to make way for sheep but for him itrsquos much more than history: the Clearances are something which can at least in part be undone. Land such as this has only been deserted for  years after millennia of occupation, and to him that means it can and should be inhabited again, a process which has become known as ldquore-peopling.He is an influential figure: author of  books on the Highlands and islands, he was the first director of the University of the Highlands and Island Centre for History, and from - was chairman of government development agency Highlands and Islands Enterprise.Now the idea of re-peopling is gaining traction, with substantial Scottish Government backing, and potential changes to planning rules.But can people be brought back to stabilise fragile communities, re-inhabit deserted glens and islands, and bring them to le again As the crow flies itrsquos  miles from Brora to the island of Ulva, off the coast of Mull. What they have in common is near-emptiness, and whatrsquos happening in Ulva is seen as a test case in re-peopling.Rhuri Munro shows me the rented home he shares with his we, Rebecca, and their children Matilda and Ross.ldquoThe walls are starting to crumble, and therersquos constant damp, he says. The leaky roof brought the ceiling down in the childrenrsquos bedroom, and they were moved to the spare room, done up at the familyrsquos expense.They donrsquot need the Raeburnrsquos heat in summer butthey donrsquot run it condensation builds up. Rhuri stabs a finger at a flaking wooden window frame: ldquoTherersquos no insulation. All the windows need replacing. You have to keep pumping your own money in and it got to the stage where we werenrsquot going to do that again.The only other inhabitant of Ulva, pensioner Barry George, lives in a cottage with its own maintenance problems. The Munros say other inhabitants left the island in recent years because of poor rented housing.If the remainder had left it would have completed a process started in . That was when Francis William Clark bought the island. In  years he reduced the population of  to . Roofs were burned to stop families ing Clark carried out evictions in person, acquiring a reputation for callousness.His family sold Ulva in  to the Howards, and it was the Howardsrsquo alleged failure to maintain homes, and lack of security of tenure, that made the Munros back a community buyout when Jamie Howard put it on the market in . For the Munros it was simple: they feared being cleared out by a new owner, like their predecessors. Rebecca says: ldquoWe saw the buyout as our only real option of control.The Duchess, the Highland Clearances, the housekeeper ... and a story to make you weepWhen, after a year of worry for the islanders, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Scottish Land Fundmade a pound.m grant, the buyout could go ahead. On June , , a couple of hundred people gathered on Ulva to celebrate its completion.The grant put the island at the forefront of the re-peopling movement. The SLF, set up to help community buyouts, paid it to the North West Mull Community Woodland Company , the organisation that actually made the purchase.To get the grant it put forward a plan for a major increase in population. As well as proposing to reinhabit existing island houses, the plan says new crofts can be established, and self-builders can have plots, with a long-term target of  people living on the island.One of the people who drew up the plan was community land consultant Calum Macleod, now policy officer for umbrella group Community Land Scotland, and a leading proponent of re-peopling.For him, spending public money to let people live lives many urban dwellers would envy is a matter of maintaining important ersity, vital to stop the inexorable draw of towns and cities.He believes Ulva is a test case: ldquoIt offers an opportunity to show where the potential can be realised for re-peopling and repopulating, he says. ldquoItrsquos not somewhere that is a wild area, there are existing houses, but itrsquos a good example of what can be done.Yorkshireman Ian Hepburn is one of the people charged with re-peopling Ulva. Hersquos a director of NWMCWC, which has forestry land and woodland crofts on Mull, and also chairs CLS. He lives at Dervaig on Mull, eight miles from Ulva.Hepburn meets me at the Ulva jetty a few months after the buyout and we roar off on a quad-bike tour of empty properties the company now owns.Plans to regenerate lost townships decimated by the Highland ClearancesAs well as cottages, there is the big house, with five main bedrooms plus ldquoservantsrsquo quarters. It echoes and the decorrsquos tatty but the property is sound: one idea is to lease it as a small family-run hotel. The old Manse, last lived in eight years ago, is decaying but Ardalum House, used briefly as a tourist hostel, could almost open for business tomorrow.Hepburn says more than  people have expresed interest in living on Ulva. ldquoThe reality and the ambition are not always in line but we will get people for sure wanting to live here when we get houses redeveloped.ldquoThe key thing is they wonrsquot be holiday homes, we want families in them, living and working. With modern telecommunications the location doesnrsquot make much dference to what you do for a living, so wersquore confident we can end up with a ing, living island relatively quickly.Many of the ideas for creating work here are tourism based, but crofts based on the productive land could each provide part of a living.ldquoWe donrsquot want to be modern-day lairds, Hepburn adds. ldquoWe want to create the potential for other people to run a business here to bring the le back.Back in Strath Brora, Jim Hunter points out that re-peopling has happened before, with the creation of crofts by the Government for former soldiers after the First World War, in Skye, the outer isles and where.Hunter says Strath Brorarsquos farmland, neglected for two centuries could be revived, and like Hepburn, believes other work will follow, with internet links a major factor.Pointing to a growing population on Skye, Hunter says when homes are available, people will come and then find or create work.Up the strath at the remains of the former schoolhouse ndash two long, tumbled walls overgrown with bracken ndash Hunter looks south to a wind farm. That kind of development too can provide funds to underpin a community, ldquo it is owned by the community, the money stays here and doesnrsquot go to an outside company.Could more community buyouts, of the Ulva type, foster more re-peopling  The islands of Eigg and Gigha have seen populations grow by % in recent years, as has Knoydart: all three are community owned. On Eigg people who want to live there do find work: some incomers farm but others are journalists, run tourist accommodation, bike hire and craft businesses, recording studios, a brewery...Hunter is a community land enthusiast but he acknowledges a problem with Ulva, Eigg, Gigha and Knoydart as templates for his ideas. ldquoCommunity buyouts can only happen where there is a community, and in places that were comprehensively cleared there are no communities.So, he says, while ownership is an issue, and a change can bring more people in, more fundamental is planning regulations.ldquoOur planning regime tends to the view that a locality such as this in Strath Brora where there is nobody living, should remain one where no-one is living, and houses and businesses are only to be encouraged where there are houses and businesses already.ldquoI can understand that but I think itrsquos not impossible to envisage these things happening in localities where people lived not all that long ago in historical termsldquoIf you look around us here there is no lack of land, there are millions of acres in the Highlands doing not an awful lot, producing not very much. When you think a very small plot where the planners have said you can build a house in many parts of the Highlands now would sell for pound,, there is something completely bizarre about it when there is so much empty land.ldquoIn any real sense that landrsquos real worth should be pound to pound ... We need to revise the planning system and make it easier for people to get house sites.He says to make it easier for people, especially young people, to live in the Highlands the Scottish Government must put together legal and planning frameworks to ensure housing can be built and the system gives priority to social and community need, not private gain.ldquoThe mechanics are not rocket science. Whatrsquos required, but what sometimes seems to be in as short supply as affordable homes, is the political will.That political will is developing: amendments agreed to the Scottish Governmentrsquos proposed Planning Bill by Holyroodrsquos Local Government and Communities Committee include giving Scottish Ministers a duty to take into account the importance of resettling rural Scotland, and of making land available for resettlement. Others, including one to let local councils include re-population as an aim in their planning blueprints, are still on the table.Historian Sir Tom Devine on what really happened during the clearancesWhen I test Hunterrsquos ideas on Brora local history enthusiast Nick Lindsay, another student of the Clearances, he is sceptical about re-population, for Strath Brora at least. He says there are few jobs in the area, adding: ldquoThere would be a huge cost of infrastructure: I donrsquot see where the money would come from. Itrsquos a romantic notion but I think the practicalities are too hard to overcome.Hersquos not the only sceptic: Ulvarsquos Jamie Howard, now a flat-dweller in Edinburgh, says of re-peopling: ldquoIt has become a bit of an obsession with the government and an exercise in flag-waving, with this willingness to wind the clock back to the Clearances. On Ulva, the SNPrsquos ideal would be an island full of people with the right accent, singing from the same hymn sheet.But Sarah Jane Laing, chief executive of landownersrsquo group Scottish Land and Estates, takes a conciliatory tone, saying her members are the biggest housing providers in the countryside and would be happy to see more homes: ldquoWersquove got members all over the Highlands and Islands desperately trying to get planning permission for housing, she says.ldquoThose of us working in land management and land reform are not that far apart ndash what we and Community Land Scotland wants is to have sustainable rural communities.Hunter says resettlement of now-wild areas can go hand-in-hand with better environmental stewardship, pointing to estate records showing wildle was more ied and prolic when Strath Brora was heavily inhabited.Perhaps surprisingly the John Muir Trust wild land charity broadly agrees, even though re-peopling could mean homes on ldquowild land.The Trustrsquos chief executive, Andrew Bachell, says truly remote areas are unlikely to be re-inhabited: ldquoMost of what you would want to do to improve the ecology would involve having people there to manage it, he says. ldquoIf wersquore talking about more people in the north-west Highlands I donrsquot think therersquos any conflict with that and the rewilding agenda, in fact wild land will be one of the reasons people want to live there.While sceptics will always question the level of Government spending on near-empty Ulva when there are other pressing needs, the people at the sharp end donrsquot doubt the dference the re-peopling project will make.Rebecca Munrorsquos battered home on Ulva will be renovated as part of the drive to improve housing stock, and she can invest more in the Boathouse Restaurant next door that she runs with sister-in-law Emma McKie.I catch the strength of emotion in Rebeccarsquos voice when she talks of a future with other children to play with hers in the evening after the ferry has stopped running. Therersquos emotion there too when she speaks of the buyoutrsquos place in history.One of her favourite places on the island is known as Starvation Point, where th-century residents cleared from their old homes and too old or too sick to leave were left to fend for themselves.ldquoItrsquos sad but itrsquos also a really inspirational place, Rebecca says. ldquoA couple of times when things got really dficult with the buyout process I went down there and I thought, lsquothese people didnrsquot have any of these opportunities wersquove had, so just suck it up and get on with it, because you can do something and they couldnrsquot.rsquoldquoItrsquos very dficult not to get upset or angry about at what was done. The villages and townships are still very visible. When the Clearances happened those people had no rights and they had no comeback about what was happening, so there was definitely a bit of righting the wrongs that were done then, in our buyout.Where did the money come from The grant of pound. million by the Scottish Government to buy Ulva was a statement of intent about re-population. But how did it come about, and did connections between Government, grant-givers and the buyout group play a part After Ulva went on the market in , the Government, unusually, put the sale on hold. Then, in October , it allowed North West Mull Community Woodland Companyto register an interest in the estate as a community buyout objective, to allow it a clear run at a deal. This is normally done before any suggestion of a sale.A bid for pound.m went to the Scottish Land Fund , which can give pound million a year of Government cash to community buyouts. Its normal upper limit for single grants is poundm, but the fund backed the bid and referred it to ministers. It was approved in May .The chair of the SLF committee, which decides grants, is John Watt. He emphasises the SLF is run independently of government.ldquoWe had to take quite a few things into consideration, the impact on the budget, the wider land reform policy, as well as the intrinsic merits of the case, he says. ldquoOur decision was that given all the factors and given our understanding of the policy context for Government objectives to ersy the land ownership pattern ... we should recommend that this should be approved.He says the fund was aware a huge grant for Ulva could hit worthy smaller projects, but the government indicated extra money would be availableUlva went ahead.In fact, the Scottish Government says, a poundm underspend on the SLFrsquos budget in - was allowed to be carried over into -, to cover most of the Ulva cash.Meanwhile those involved in the bid say they maintain a professional distance between dferent aspects of their work, and no undue influence was brought to bear on the Scottish Government or the SLF.Calum MacLeod was a member of the Scottish Land Fund committee from its start in  until March . In July  he was engaged as one of three consultants to write the feasibility study submitted to the fund by NWMCWC to support the Ulva bid.Since then he has become part-time policy officer for Community Land Scotland , the prominent umbrella group that makes much of its income from work for the Scottish Government. He previously carried out projects for CLS, Highlands and Islands Enterprise and the Scottish Parliament. He says there is no suggestion his connections helped propel the Ulva grant application.Duncan MacPherson, who has worked extensively with community buyouts and was another of the Ulva consultants, is a member of the SLF committee, and was when the Ulva application was submitted.He declared an interest and took no part in discussions about Ulva, saying: ldquoI went on the committee to make sure people with experience of the sector took part in decisions ... The committee met separately to discuss the Ulva bid and I wasnrsquot even in the building.Ian Hepburn, a director of NWMCWC, also chairs CLS.Hepburn says: ldquoIn terms of did I take an active part in [the SLF grant application] or speak to anyone at the Scottish Government about it, I absolutely did not.

title: joanna-blythman-im-just-so-grateful-not-to-be-paying-for-this-meal-with-my-own-money
story: Irsquom here because One Square has a new chef. You certainly wouldnrsquot come for the experience. Although the restaurant is almost empty wersquore sat at a cramped window table. Normally yoursquod want a window table. Theoretically speaking, this could have a phenomenal view over to the Usher Hall and the castle, were it not for the eyesores in our foreground: a concrete wall, crowd control barriers flapping with plastic hazard tape, and that weird grey igloo thing. Hard to know whether the latter is the councilrsquos idea of an artwork, or a would-be futurist architectrsquos shed for street sweepersrsquo equipment. The other thing thatrsquos wrong with our table is that itrsquos squashed in beside the service station. Seated, my dining partnerrsquos head is about a foot away from our waitressrsquos elbow as she keys in orders. This table is snug in the wrong way. I guess itrsquos not a load of laughs to work here, perhaps that why our waitress clomps up and down gracelessly like the chatelaine of a boarding house, laying other tables loudly, possibly resentfully. In a film, shersquod be played by Olivia Coleman.Therersquos a produce map of Scotland on the menu. It talks virtuously of finest Scottish ingredients, local suppliers, seasonality, and so on. Judging from it my braised beef skirt should come from Berwickshire. Perhaps it does, but what fate befell it in these kitchens  It hangs off the fork in dry, grey strands, like an old string mop head the cleaner has left to dry. In place of the promised horseradish therersquos sweet, gluey mayonnaise. This meat is propped up on friseacutee ene, half a slice of indferent rye bread, the long-le, sliced commercial type, under stray circles of vinegary shallot. At least this starter is from the fixed price menu, so only pound, but the ldquoshellfish with Thistly Cross cider and shallots costs pound, and a meaner dish would be hard to find. Itrsquos topped by a midget langoustine: all inedible head, and inconsequential, meat-challenged tail. Therersquos a small handful each of mussels that are barely big enough to consider as food, and unsubstantial clams. The most worrying element though is the queen scallops. Whatever their journey to our table, theyrsquove had a total flavour bypass. This dish doesnrsquot smell nice. The taste is creamy with a jarring dried herb presence, no apparent fish stock, let alone cider.And now Irsquom staring in disbelief at this skate wing. pound, yet I have never seen a smaller one. It looks lost and lonely on its big white plate, dressed with a little butter and few broken up capers that have not been improved by deep-frying. Does the Sheraton instruct its seafood supplier to provide it with the smallest, meanest specimens on the slab : Ron Mackenna restaurant review: Errolrsquos Hot Pizza,  Victoria Road, GlasgowPollock from the fixed price menu, although not singing out freshness, is adequately cooked. I could almost get enthusiastic about the yellow-fleshed salad potatoes it comes with until I taste the ldquoHollandaise sauce that tops them: like floury Beacutechamel mixed with vinegar. These ribbons of cabbage are so long they could choke you. Their dressing adds a taint of stale garlic and poor oil, a palate polluter.We gingerly sample a Tarte Tatin of French motorway service station standard, with clotted cream ice cream that evokes the greasy, sweet odour of an old tea towel thatrsquos been lying around in a bakery for too long. A creamy rice pudding, stippled with vanilla seeds, needs more than this stingy teaspoon of rhubarb pureacutee to stop it being cloying.Irsquom just so grateful not to be paying for this meal with my own money. I wonder how many of Sheratonrsquos hotel guests feel the same.One Square,  Festival Square, Edinburgh   Food:  Atmosphere:  Service:  Value for money:  Joanna BlythmanGuild of Food Writers Food Writer of the Year

title: members-wont-mention-theresa-may-on-doorsteps-as-tories-prepares-for-election-drubbing
story: The Prime Minister has become synonymous with ldquobetrayal over Brexit in votersrsquo minds, leading some activists to try to focus on local issues, rather the Governmentrsquos main goal.Tory HQ has even registered a name iation with the Electoral Commission that allows the candidates to appear on ballot papers as ldquoLocal Conservatives, downplaying any link with the PM.Professor Sir John Curtice of Strathclyde University said Mrs Mayrsquos failure to deliver Brexit was doing ldquoserious damage to her partyrsquos electoral prospects, with a flood of Leave voters switching to Ukip and, above all, Nigel Faragersquos new Brexit Party.Writing in the , Sir John said the European elections could be a ldquoperfect storm of protests for the Tories, noting the partyrsquos support had fallen a dramatic  points since Mrs May unveiled her Brexit deal in November.More than  seats are being contested in English local elections on May , most of them currently Tory held.The potential extension of Brexit until October  also means the UK must take part in EU elections on May , unless MPs can agree a Brexit deal by then.With no sign of a breakthrough in talks between the Government and Labour, or consensus in the Commons, all parties are now campaigning on the assumption the poll goes ahead.However some associations have refused to campaign for their own party, including the Derbyshire Conservatives, who ldquooverwhelmingly voted not to support their own party in the EU poll.The Brighton and Hove local Conservative Association banned discussion of Brexit as it is so isive.Mrs Mayrsquos unpopularity threatens to disrupt Ruth Davidsonrsquos imminentto frontline politics after a six-month maternity break.The Scottish Tory leader backed Mrs May for the Tory leadership in .ldquoI can say without hesitation that I believe Theresa May is best placed to navigate the stormy waters ahead, Ms Davidson said at the time.Ms Davidson is due toto the public eye at her party conference in Aberdeen on May , but the event will be dominated by the overnight results from the English council elections, especiallyMrs May is a speaker.Ed Costelloe, chairman of Grassroots Conservatives, said of the English fight: ldquoCampaigners and candidates are only talking about whatrsquos happening at a local level, because the frustration they are hearing about whatrsquos going on at a national level is virtually universal.ldquoMost of the people out there canvassing have a lot of experience and they are saying this is worse than anything they have experienced before.The Scottish Tories announced their European candidates yesterday. Incumbent MEP Baroness Nosheena Mobarik tops the six-person Scotlandwide list followed by Scottish Borders councillor Shona Haslam, and perennial hopeful Iain McGill.Iain Whyte, the Tory group leader on Edinburgh City Council, Andrea Gee, who works for East Renfrewshire MP Paul Masterton, and Aberdeen solicitor Michael Kusznir make up the bottom half of the slate.The SNP also announced its shortlist of six candidates, who will now be ranked in the coming days by delegates to this monthrsquos conference.Sitting MEP Alyn Smith, former MSP Christian Allard and Glasgow activist Alex Kerr are one half of the genderbalanced list. Former minister Aileen McLeod, former MP Margaret Ferrier, and Borders Councillor Heather Anderson make up the other.Scottish Labour and the Scottish LibDems have already announced their candidates, and the Scottish Greens are due to name theirs on Thursday. David Coburn, who won a Scottish seat for Ukip in , last night refused to sayhe was standing for the Brexit Party. Like most of its MEPs, he recently left Ukip over its drt to the far right.

title: people-more-open-to-case-for-independence-over-brexit-says-sturgeon
story: Writing in our sister publication,The National,the First Minister set out her vision for what an independent Scotland could look like, as well asaddressing the economic case including the question of currency.Ms Sturgeon also said that it is the responsibility of independence supporters to persuade others that it is the best answer to the current questions faced.ldquoIn , many who ultimately voted No were open to persuasion, The First Minister wrote.ldquoWith Brexit destroying any sense that the UK offers a stable and prosperous future for Scotland, there are even more people now open to the arguments for an independent Scotland.ldquoSo the responsibility of all of us who support independence is to persuade those who are open-minded that it is the best answer to the questions we face.The First Minister also addressed the report published by the Sustainable Growth Commission, stating that it is not and was not intended to be a ldquopolicy manesto for the entire Yes movement, but would instead provide a framework and options for addressing challenges.Ms Sturgeon added that the report demonstrates the untapped economic potential of the country.On the question of currency, the First Minister said that the complexities and challenges involved with adopting an independent currency should not be oversimplied, also stating that an independent currency would not be ldquoa magic wand that cures all economic ills.However, Ms Sturgeon said that it would be important to give people the confidence that a transition process to an independent currency would be ldquowell planned and ldquorobustly governed, as well as being in the interests of citizens and businesses.Writing ahead of the SNP conference in Edinburgh next weekend, the First Minister added that dferent views both within and outwith the Yes movement are ldquoperfectly legitimate and said that open and honest debate is a strength of the independence movement.She wrote: ldquoTalking about the opportunities of independence is much more positive than resigning ourselves to the deep despair of Brexit.ldquoTurning our debates into reality depends on winning a majority for independence ndash and that means persuading Scotland in all its ersity that it is the best way forward. It is that task, more than any, that unites our movement. And it is that task to which we must devote our energies.Scottish Conservative interim leader Jackson Carlaw accused the First Minister of choosing to focus on independence, rather than addressing issues such as education.Mr Carlaw said:ldquoIt is depressing but not surprising that, ahead of the SNP conference, Nicola Sturgeon is once again focusing on her plans for independence, rather than the key challenges that Scotland faces right now.ldquoScotland said no to independence nearly five years ago. Most people want to move on, but itrsquos clear that Nicola Sturgeon wonrsquot let it go.ldquoWe either face years more of Nicola Sturgeon putting her obsession before everything , or we can have a fresh government led by Ruth Davidson which wants to get on now with making Scotland a better place for everyone.

title: the-cool-list-20-scottish-golf-courses-every-fan-must-play
story: This country was made for golf and has some of the coolest courses on the planet.From hidden gems ranging through the machair to the great destination championship courses, we list  every golfer should put on their bucket list.Therersquos so much to lure the golf-lover here, not least itrsquos history: the fact, for instance, that it was the stage for one of golfrsquos ultimate duels, between Henrik Stenson and Phil Mickelson in a head-to-head that Jack Nicklaus has said even trumped his duel in the sun.What began as a six-holer in the s, dreamt up in a pub by golf enthusiasts, was expanded over the s.It also features one of the worldrsquos most well-known holes and the shortest in Open Championship, ldquoPostage Stamp th, with its tiny green, surrounded by bunkers.Itrsquos a little hole that, as Troon local, Colin Montgomerie has put it, ldquoyoursquove got to treat with an awful lot of respect.Golf Monthly says, ldquoDepending on the strength and direction of the wind, the Old Course can be a serious challenge.Green fees: poundMachrihanish Dunes is the new kid on the sands, opened in  on a stretch of coast that has hosted the nearby Machrihanish course since .Gently, with the lightest touch possible, it has been created in a Site Of Scientic Interest and home to five dferent types of orchid.Its designer David McLay Kidd described it as a ing of golf to how it should be played: ldquoNo longer is it a gentle walk in a garden, it will be a full-fledged mountaineering expedition.As a result, with five tees at the oceanrsquos edge and grass mostly mown by sheep not machines, it feels like playing in nature.Plus, therersquos the comfort of the revamped Ugdale hotel to stay in after your adventure in the wild.Green fees - ldquohome of golf experience, among them the so-called New Course, built in  by Tom Morris, and the truly newest course, The Castle, designed by David McLay Kidd.Green fees: poundGolf Digest described the West Links course at North Berwick as ldquothe most underrated golf course in the world".In other words, what is incredible is that, although it is a championship course that has hosted many played on its original fairways.The links offers plenty of hazards: snaking stone walls, giant swales, and the sea itself, when the tide sweeps in.As the club says, ldquoAll of these hazards are an important part of our history.Green fees: poundIt looked a while back asMachrie on Islay had had its day as a golfing destination.What had once been the go-to spot during the Blair years for politicos secretary.Now redeveloped this spot ndash spreading out over the dunes of Islay ndash is a golferrsquos dream.Visitors can stay in a luxury, high-ceilinged hotel, opened in Summer , relaxing on their outdoor terrace while looking out over the links, which have received a redesign by DJ Russell.Green fees: poundRanging over Harrisrsquos most breath-takingly spectacular beach, Scarista golf course has been described as one of the most picturesque -hole courses in the world.The Isle of Harris golf club was first set up in , and is now owned by its owners after they purchased it in .Therersquos nothing  quite like it ndash with its challenging natural hazards, and distracting views of the gorgeous white sands of the nearby beaches.Green fees: poundA short par- -hole Old Tom Morris course, which Global Golfer has described as ldquothe epitome of quirkiness.And rightly so ndash itrsquos littered with old-style, idiosyncrasies, revellings in the fun of the landscape.One of these is the Boar Crag, an ft high lump of red rock rising out of the links, around which a quartet of exhilarating holes revolves.Green fees: poundRated the number one golf course in the Glasgow area according to Golf World Top , Cawder offers so many charms, with its views of the Campsie hills, glimpses of the Kelvin and woodland settings as well as city-proximity convenience ndash not to mention a th century mansion as a clubhouse.You also know yoursquove got something challenging to deal with when you come across a series of holes billed, by a sign, as ldquoCawderrsquos Amen Corner. If anything deserves the term ldquohidden gem this does.Green fees: poundIt says a lot about the nature of wild Shiskine that many of its holes are blind.Located on the Isle Of Arran, looking out over the Mull of Kintyre and the Kilbrannan Sound, itrsquos unconventional in its ways and idiosyncratic in its features.Top  Golf Courses have described this course as ldquoa shrine to the way golf used to be played and noted that the course owes ldquoonly the barest influence to the hand of man.A short -holer racking up a cult reputation.Green fees: poundSituated down the end of a windy road and tucked between Lossiemouth and Hopeman, the nine holes of Covesea follow the contours of a cove, delivering dramatic views of the coast in both directions.A course for the beginners and the experienced alike ndash with a philosophy of links golf for everyone.Green fees: poundThe East Lothian coastline has plenty of golf courses, but few that deliver this feeling of discovery.Hidden in Aberlady Bay, which became the first British nature reserve in , it is reached by a private, single-track road.Here, its possible to catch a glimpse of sea-birds ing for food or seals flop on the flats, while tackling its par- -hole course.Green fees: poundA modern classic, designed by Mark Parsinner and Kyle Phillips in , Kingsbarns is a man-made course stretching along two miles of coastline, just seven miles from St Andrews.It didnrsquot take long for it to became a favourite with many golfers - Anna Nordqvist included - or for it to make its mark by hosting the annual Alfred Dunhill Links Championship.Year after year it keeps winning awards, including the  Scottish Golf Tourismrsquos Best Experience award.But golfing isnrsquot new to this stretch. There was a nine-hole golf course on the site from , which was lost when the area was mined during the Second World War.Green fees: poundDoug Carrick, famed for his courses in his native Canada, designed this -hole championship course which opened in .One of the great inland courses, it has been described as having ldquothe most beautul water hazard in the world in the shape of Loch Lomond, and boasts a string of stunning views, including that from the th hole, Tappet Doon, its most northerly point.Itrsquos also your best hopeyou fancy a round near the Bonnie Banks, since Loch Lomond club itself is renowned as one of the hardest courses to get on in Scotland.The Carrick also has all the perks of being part of a luxury resort, including a spa attached to the clubhouse ndash though sadly not, currently, a hotel, since Cameron House, which was devastated by a fire isnrsquot planned to reopen until next year.Green fees: poundGreen fees listed are generally for a single round visitor in peak season.
